conclusion: For a fixed amount of an ideal gas the equation of state is p V = n R T (n R is the same for every state of the given mass of gas).
Read the co-ordinates of the two required states from the p-V diagram: State C: p_C = 5 × 10⁵ Pa, V_C = 2 × 10⁻³ m³; State B: p_B = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V_B = 5 × 10⁻³ m³.

premise: State C: p_C = 5 × 10⁵ Pa, V_C = 2 × 10⁻³ m³
conclusion: Compute p V for state C: p_C V_C = (5 × 10⁵ Pa)(2 × 10⁻³ m³) = 1.0 × 10³ J

premise: State B: p_B = 2 × 10⁵ Pa, V_B = 5 × 10⁻³ m³
conclusion: Compute p V for state B: p_B V_B = (2 × 10⁵ Pa)(5 × 10⁻³ m³) = 1.0 × 10³ J
Since p V has the same value in both states, the right-hand side n R T must be the same, i.e. T_B = T_C.
The temperature at C is given: T_C = 300 K.
